primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The prophet Jeremiah must perform a concrete act of investment (buying land) to manifest a future hope that God promises despite national collapse.

tekstueel_bewijs: He paid seventeen shekels of silver.
He was very careful to complete the full process.
Houses and fields and vineyards shall again be bought.

zender.identificatie: The Word of the Lord / God
tekstueel_bewijs: He is instructed by the word of the Lord.
God commanded him to deal, in hope.
The land will have a flourishing future.
The neighborhood as a place of newness.
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is urged to identify with the Subject (Jeremiah) as an investor.

tekstueel_bewijs: The promise is against present circumstance.
The bread that feeds the world.
helper.rol_van_god: God is primarily the Sender (giving the command) and the Helper (providing the promise), but the human is the active Subject.
helper.rol_van_geest: Absent; replaced by 'the word' as an external mandate.

tekstueel_bewijs: The armies marched and the bombs exploded.
The poor who embarrass and inconvenience us.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is framed as the 'data' or 'circumstances' that make hope seem irrational.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God raising the body of Jesus (The Resurrection).
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: God
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The resurrection of Jesus is used as a 'proof' or 'template' to justify the human Subject's investment in the neighborhood.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God will see to it that the whole land will prosper.
God took his body and raised him up.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: He paid seventeen shekels of silver.
You have to say something new.

voorbeelden: He was commanded to pay for it.
He had to keep the family farm.
I would rather bet against the poor.
We would rather live in a safe, guarded place.
He knew it was the word of the Lord.
I know you do not care about this ancient property.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon is heavily driven by obligation (Devoir). The hearer is told what they must do (bet/invest) to unlock the future.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Jerusalem's collapse) to ~S1 (Cynicism) to S1 (The act of buying/betting).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by human action (the purchase) authorized by a divine promise.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Moderate; while collapse is mentioned, it is treated as a backdrop for the human 'bet'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While using the language of 'God's future,' the engine of the sermon is human agency. The 'bet' is something the hearer must do to participate in the future.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: When you bet on the neighborhood... the words keep sounding.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God will see to it that the whole land will prosper.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Jeremiah is presented as the model investor whose 'careful process' we must replicate in our social context.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: God is the one who buys back the 'worthless' field of humanity at the cost of His Son.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Pressure to 'bet' correctly or feel guilty for 'betting against' the neighborhood.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Synergism: God provides the future, but human investment is the 'wedge' that opens it.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from Jeremiah to Jesus to the neighborhood is rhetorically smooth but actantially inconsistent.
spanning_punten: The sermon claims God raised Jesus (God as Subject), but then tells the hearer to 'bet on the body' (Man as Subject).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The little land purchase becomes a wedge for a new world.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The hearer is expected to have the 'Vouloir' (will) based on the sermon's exhortation.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is being 'out of sync' or 'betting against' the right things.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon functions as a 'call to action' where the hearer is the Subject and God is the Sender of a difficult mandate.

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The hearer is the one who must 'bet' to make the future happen.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: God is the Great Investor who 'bets' on us when we are worthless.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'You must bet on the farm,' use 'God has already bought the farm of our broken lives.'

identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that we are the ones being 'bought' and 'redeemed' by God's investment.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Focus on how the Resurrection gives us the power to love the neighborhood, rather than just the duty to do so.

tegenstander_intensivering.voorgestelde_intensivering: The impossibility of human hope in the face of death.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: Only a 'Heavy Opponent' makes the 'Subject-switch' to Christ necessary.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: God has bought the world (Soteriology) -> Therefore we live in that reality (Ethics).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon has a strong social conscience, but it risks turning the Gospel into a high-stakes gamble for the hearer.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorically, the 'betting' metaphor is engaging; actantially, it places the burden of the future on the hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis focuses on Jeremiah's context; semiotics reveals that the preacher has made the hearer the 'new Jeremiah'.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that 'God' is a Sender who remains on the sidelines while the 'Hearer-Subject' does the heavy lifting.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'grace-adjacent' language (Resurrection, Table) but maintains a legalistic actantial structure.
